When nitrogen monoxide (NO) was contacted with Cu/mordenite at room temperature, the evolution of dinitrogen monoxide (NZO) and nitrogen occurred, accompanied by the formation of the adsorbed oxygen species (Os). In the TPD runs, three NO desorption peaks appeared, with maxima at 383 K (a-NO peak), 523 K (NO peak), and 673 K ('y-NO peak). The desorptions of oxygen and nitrogen dioxide (NOZ) were observed together with the desorption of NO at 673 K. These a-NO and NO peaks correspond to the desorptions of nitrogen oxide species which adsorbed as NO-type species. The desorptions of -y-NO, -y-N02 and 'y-OZ at 673 K arose from the decomposition of N03-type adsorbed species. The N03-type species may have formed by the reaction between NO and the adsorbed oxygen species (Os). By comparison of the rate of the NO decomposition with that of the decomposition of N03-type adsorbed species, it was shown that the N03-type adsorbed species plays a pivotal role in the decomposition of NO as intermediate of the reaction. 1998 Elsevier Science B.V. Keywords: Cu/mordenite; Nitrogen monoxide; Direct decomposition; Characterization; Temperature programmed desorption; Infrared 1. Introduction The catalytic decomposition of NO and NOZ is the simplest and the most desirable method for their removal. Numerous papers concerning the catalytic decomposition of NO and NOZ have recently been published [1-16]. In particular, high-silica zeolites containing Cu 2+ have shown pronounced activity for the NO decomposition [4-10]. The experimental *Corresponding author. PI/S0926-860X(97)00268-8 data suggested that the reaction proceeds via a redoxtype mechanism [8]. A fraction of Cu 2+ ions is reduced to Cu+ through spontaneous desorption of oxygen. Oxidation of Cu' ions with NO generates Cu2+ ions and forms NZ in the gas phase [4,7]. Researchers therefore concluded that the reducible Cu2+ located in the zeolite framework plays an important role in the catalytic decomposition of NO over Cue+-exchanged zeolites. Iwamoto et al. [6] showed that nitrosyl species such as NO and/or (NO)26- located at Cu' sites were involved in the decomposition of NO as intermediates 216 M. Shimokawabe et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 166 (1998) 215-223 of the reaction. Valyon and Hall [9] suggested that the higher catalytic activity of the high-silica zeolites could be ascribed to the formation of more stable complexes of copper nitrosyls on the zeolites than on low-silica zeolites. They also discussed another possible decomposition mechanism involving NO-CuNOZ intermediates, which were supposed to be formed by reactions of NO with extralattice oxygen atoms (ELO) associated with Cue+. They tentatively explained that the Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts were much more active than Cu/Y because of the higher stability of the intermediate species. Aylor et al. [ 12] showed that the first step of NO decomposition over Cu/ZSM5 is the formation of N20 via the decomposition of Cu+(NO)2. N2 is then formed via the reaction of N20 with Cu+ sites. OZ formation is envisioned to proceed via the release of O atoms from Cu 2'0- and the subsequent reaction of O atoms with additional Cu 2+0- to produce Cue+OZ . It has also been shown that Cu/mordenite exhibited high catalytic activity for the NO decomposition [3,4,13,14]. However, only a limited number of papers have been published on the mechanism of the NO decomposition over Cu/ mordenite [16]. In the present study, the structures and the desorption behavior of NO, species formed on Cu/mordenite catalysts were studied by means of diffuse reflectance FT-IR spectroscopy and a thermal desorption method. It was shown that NO, species such as nitrates and/or nitrosyls are formed and stabilized on the surface of Cu/mordenite. By comparisons between the rates of the NO decomposition and those of the decomposition of the nitrate species, we showed that the nitrate species which formed plays a pivotal role in the NO decomposition over Cu/mordenite catalysts. 2. Experimental 2.1. Catalysts Cu/mordenite catalysts were prepared by an ionexchange method in an aqueous solution of copper prepared from copper(II) acetate (Wako Pure Chemicals, extra pure grade) and an aqueous solution of ammonia. The ion-exchanged mordenite was filtered out, washed with distilled water and dried at 383 K for 12 h, and was further calcined in air for 3 h at 773 K. Na-mordenite (JRC-Z-M-20, Si02/A1203=20) was supplied from the Catalysis Society of Japan. Copper loadings were 1.0, 2.0, 3.1 and 3.7 wt%. The amounts of copper loadings were calculated from the difference of copper(II) concentration of the solution before and after the ion exchange. The amounts of copper(II) ions were determined by titration with an EDTA solution of known concentration using of 1-(2-Pyridylazo)-2naphthol (PAN) as an indicator. The structure of copper of Cu/mordenite was inspected by UVNIS/NIR diffuse reflectance spectroscopy. The spectra were measured in ex situ mode on a UV/VIS/NIR spectrophotometer (Hitachi Model 330) with a diffuse reflectance attachment (Hitachi model 210-2101). 2.2. NO decomposition The reactant gas used was 30 or 4 vol% NO (Sumitomo Seika) diluted with helium. The reaction was carried out in a conventional flow reactor at W/F (W weight of a catalyst (g); F -total flow rate (cm 3/S)) Of 0.6 g s cm-3 and at 573-773 K. The reactor was made of 12 mm diameter quartz tubing in which the catalyst sample (0.5 g) was mounted on loosely packed quartz wool. The concentrations of NO, NZO, Nz and Oz in the outflow gas were determined by the use of gas chromatographs (Ohkura Electric, Model 701 and Yanagimoto Model G-2000) with porapak Q and molecular sieve 5A columns. The concentration of NOZ was monitored by means of a UV/VIS spectrophotometer (Hitachi Model 100-50). 2.3. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) Prior to the TPD runs, the catalysts were treated in the reactor at 773 K for 3 h and cooled to room temperature in a stream of He. 30 vol% NO diluted with He was then fed over a catalyst at room temperature for given periods of time, and was purged by switching to a pure He stream until no NO was detected in the outflow. Programmed heating was started from room temperature to 773 K at a rate of 10 K min-1. The amounts of gases desorbed were estimated from the peak areas of the temperature programmed desorption (TPD). NO was purified by passage through a trap containing a molecular sieve 13X cooled in dry ice-methanol. M. Shimokawabe et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 166 (1998) 215-223 2.4. Diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy Infrared spectra of surface nitrogen oxide species were recorded by means of a Fourier transform-infrared (FT-IR) spectrophotometer (Nihon Bunko FT-IR5 M) with a diffuse reflectance attachment (Nihon Bunko DG-500/H). The powdered catalyst was placed on the sample cell in the diffuse reflectance attachment. 30 vol% NO diluted with He was fed over the catalyst at room temperature for given periods of time, and was purged by switching to a pure He stream at temperatures between room temperature and 673 K. The IR measurement of adsorbed species was then carried out at room temperature. 3. Results and discussion 3.1. The desorption behavior of surface NO, species formed on Culmordenite Fig. 1 illustrates the typical TPD curves for the NO, species on Cu/mordenite (3.1 wt% copper) pretreated at 773 K in He. These species were formed by adsorption in a flow of 30 vol% NO on the catalyst at room temperature for 0.17, 0.5, 1, 2.5, 15, 60, 120 and 420 min. Various desorption peaks appear. The peaks occurring in the temperature ranges of <473 K, 473593 K, 593-723 K and >753 K are henceforth referred to as a-, , 7- and peaks, respectively. No desorption took place in TPD runs over the mordenite alone. This suggests that the TPD peaks resulted from NO, species adsorbed on the copper. As previously suggested by many authors [3-10], NO2 is most probably produced by reaction of OZ formed by NO decomposition with a large excess of unreacted NO in the path from the outlet of the reactor to the gas analysis system. At the reaction temperatures lower than 623 K, N20 was formed in preference to NZ. At higher temperatures, the formation of N20 decreases. NZ increases at the expense of Nz0. This suggests that NZ is produced through the steps 2N0-->N20+(1/2)02 and NZO -->N2+(1/2)02. Fig. 7 illustrates the TPD curves of NO, species formed on Cu/mordenite with 3.1 wt% copper subjected to the NO decomposition at 673 K. The adsorbed species were rapidly quenched to 573 K in a He stream after achievement of a steady state of the reaction; the TPD heating started at 573 K. The desorption peaks of -y-NO, -y-N02 and 'y-OZ were observed around 673 K. The value of O/N ratio calculated for -y-peaks of NO, NO2 and OZ was also 3, suggesting that N03-type adsorbed species are formed under a steady state of the reaction at 673 K. Fig. 8 shows the infrared spectra of the NO., species formed on Cu/mordenite with 3.1 wt% copper under a steady state of the reaction in 30 vol% NO at 673 K. The absorption band at 1900 cm- t arises from NO in the gas phase. The band assigned to M < NO appears at 1570 cm-1 along with the bands ascribed to (NO)2 at 1735 and 1829 cm-t, confirming that N03-type adsorbed species are formed at a steady state of NO decomposition. The precursor structure of copper on Cu/mordenite with copper loadings of 1.0-3.7 wt% was investigated by means of the diffuse reflectance UVNIS spectroscopy. Cu/mordenite was treated in air at 773 K prior to measuring of UV/VIS spectra. The catalyst would be covered with surface oxygen (Os). The absorption band which appeared at 270 nm is ascribed to charge transfer between surface oxygen and Cu 2+ ion in octahedral co-ordination [20]. The reflectivity at 270 nm is thus proportional to the concentration of the surface cupric ion over Cu/mordenite. A good relationship exists between these parameters. This suggests that N03-type adsorbed species was formed on the surface copper species in octahedral co-ordination. 4. Conclusion The structures and the desorption behavior of adsorbed NO, species were studied by means of diffuse reflectance FT-IR spectroscopy and thermal desorption method. It was found that various adsorbed NO, species were formed and stabilized on the surface of Cu/mordenite. The desorptions of NO, N02 and OZ at 673 K arose from the decomposition of N03-type adsorbed species. The N03-type adsorbed species may have formed by the reaction between NO and the adsorbed oxygen species. By comparison of the rate of the NO decomposition with that of the decomposition of N03-type adsorbed species, it is shown that N03type adsorbed species plays a pivotal role in the decomposition of NO as an intermediate of the reaction.
